Graphical abstract The Co2C-based catalyst is a promising candidate for the Fischer-Tropsch to olefins reaction. However, it consistently exhibits high CO2 selectivity (∼40 %), and the origin of the high activity in the water–gas-shift reaction is not well-understood. In this study, Co2C catalysts constructed with the same elemental compositions but using the melting and co-precipitation methods resulted in drastic differences in CO2 selectivity − one at 3.8 % and the other at 35.3 %. A detailed structural study revealed that the presence of CoxMn1-xO instead of Co2C is responsible for the elevated CO2 selectivity. Interestingly, CoxMn1-xO alone demonstrates limited CO2 selectivity, but when promoted with Na, its WGSR activity is greatly enhanced. Conversely, the catalysts maintained consistently low CO2 selectivity even with improved Na content, as long as a high fraction of Co2C is present. This finding is important for designing Co2C-based catalysts that can achieve high olefin selectivity while minimizing undesirable CO2 emissions. Keywords Fischer-Tropsch synthesis to olefins Co2C Olefins CO2 selectivity Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Short-chain olefins (C2-C4 olefins) are commonly used chemical raw materials in the industry, serving as crucial components in various basic chemical products [1–4]. Conventional olefin production primarily relies on naphtha cracking. With the depletion of fossil resources and the increasing demand for olefins, non-petroleum routes have been proposed and developed to supplement the olefin production. Coal [5–7], natural gas [8–11], or biomass [12–14] serve as effective alternative feedstocks for generating short-chain olefins via syngas (a mixture of CO and H2) as an intermediate platform [15–21]. Recently, syngas conversion to olefins has attracted significant attention from both academia and industry. Among these methods, Fischer-Tropsch to olefins (FTO) is one of the favorable pathways to directly convert syngas to olefins [22–24]. In recent years, both Fe- and Co-based catalysts have made substantial progress in enhancing selectivity towards short-chain olefins [25–27].De Jong and co-workers [26] reported a Na/S-modified loaded iron-based catalyst for FTO, which has a 61 % lower olefin selectivity at a limited CO conversion (<1.0 %). Zhong et al. [28] reported that Co2C nano-prisms with (101) and (020) exposed surfaces exhibited 31.8 % CO conversion, 60.8 % lower olefin selectivity and a 5.0 % CH4 fraction during syngas reforming. Bao's group [29] used a bifunctional oxide zeolite catalyst (OX-ZEO) to convert syngas directly to low-grade olefins with up to 80 % selectivity. However, the increased olefin selectivity is accompanied by high CO2 production. If the calculation of product selectivity is based on the converted CO, the olefin selectivity decreases significantly. During the conversion of syngas to olefins, carbon dioxide is a common by-product, so it becomes important to avoid the formation of CO2. Syngas-to-olefin conversion is often accompanied by the water–gas-shift reaction (WGSR) [30–33]; therefore, inhibiting CO2 formation − by ensuring high C atom utilization − remains a key hurdle in syngas to olefin conversion [5,34]. The process of converting syngas into hydrocarbons primarily involves breaking the C-O bond to create dissociated O atoms to form H2O and/or CO2. The produced H2O may adsorb on the WGSR-active site to produce extra CO2 [35]. The H2O produced can adsorb onto reactive sites, which promotes the WGSR and generates additional CO2. Researchers have tried various approaches to mitigate CO2 formation in the FTO reaction. One effective method to achieve reduced CO2 selectivity is to modify the catalyst surface with hydrophobic promoters. For instance, Ding et al. [36] reported hydrophobic core–shell FeMn@SiO2 catalysts that suppressed the selectivity to CO2 and CH4 to below 22.5 % during the FTO reaction, while maintaining approximately 65 % olefin selectivity. Similar strategies have been employed to synthesize Co-based catalysts for FTO reaction from syngas and a Cu-based catalyst for the production of dimethyl ether (DME) [30]. Lin et al. [37] designed a silica-coated Co2C catalyst for the FTO reaction, and reported that the silica coating facilitated rapid water removal from the active site, which reduced CO2 selectivity from 45 % to about 15 % under similar CO conversion levels. Xie et al. [38] reported Na/S/Mn-modified hcp Co used for the FTO reaction, with 54 % short-chain olefin selectivity and a < 3 % CO2 fraction at 240 °C and 1 bar. However, the CO conversion was also largely sacrificed. The strategy of modifying the surface of the catalysts with hydrophobic promoters only prevents H2O from participating in the WGSR and consequently reduces CO2 selectivity, but it does not address the fundamental cause of high CO2 selectivity in the Co2C-based catalyst itself. Li's group [39] reported a Co1Mn3 oxide nanocomposite with C2 =∼C4 = selectivity of up to 65.4 % and a CO2 selectivity of 13.7 %. It was also reported that CO2 emissions could be minimized by Co0 clusters (<1 nm) being formed as active sites that could inhibit WGSR. Liu and his coworkers [40] suggested that the exclusion Co oxide in a Co2C-based catalyst derived from Co2MnO4.5 could effectively reduce CO2 selectivity. Zafari et al. [41] investigated the effect of a novel Ce and Zn double-decorated Co–Mn catalyst supported on silica for CO hydrogenation to olefins. The cyclic oxidation process of CeO2 can effectively inhibit the oxidation of Co atoms during the WGSR, which leads to lower CO2 levels. These studies reveal that suppressing the formation of Co oxides always leads to lower WGSR activity. However, there is still not a comprehensive understanding of the mechanisms that causes high WGSR activity in Co2C-based catalysts or of the crucial role played by the additive Na. In this study, we employed melting and co-precipitation methods with identical elemental compositions to obtain Co2C-based catalysts for the FTO reaction. Remarkably, the catalyst prepared via the melting method achieved very low CO2 production, whereas the co-precipitation method achieved high CO2 selectivity. The detailed characterization results show that Co-Mn does not undergo significant phase separation, leading to the limited formation of Co2C. The remaining CoxMn1-xO in the catalyst contributes to the high CO2 selectivity. The meticulous characterization done revealed that the inability of Co-Mn to undergo the significant phase separation that leads to CoxMn1-xO is the origin of high CO2 selectivity. In order to explore the intrinsic WGSR activity of the catalysts, we conducted probe experiments using identical H2O and CO partial pressure levels. Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations were employed to validate the different adsorption energies of H2O on CoxMn1-xO and Co2C. The influence of Na on CO2 selectivity was examined comprehensively, which clarified that CoxMn1-xO itself does not exhibit high WGSR activity, but with Na promotion, its WGSR activity is strongly enhanced. Finally, the mechanism governing WGSR activity in Co2C-based catalysts is proposed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation N-Co2MnO4.5 was prepared using the co-precipitation method. Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 50 wt% Mn(NO3)2 were mixed in a 2:1 M ratio of Co to Mn. This formed a 2 M solution. The precipitant (NH4)2CO3 was prepared (separately) in a solution using the same concentration. The precipitation reaction took place in a water bath at 30 °C by dropping the two solutions into a flask while stirring vigorously. The pH value was controlled at 8.0 ± 0.2. After precipitation, the resulting precipitate was aged at 60 °C for 2 h. Subsequently, the filtered-out precipitate was washed with deionized water until the pH reached 7.0. It was then dried at 110 °C for 12 h, and the resulting solid was calcined in a muffle furnace under an air atmosphere at 330 °C for 3 h, in order to obtain the unpromoted Co-Mn catalyst. To further promote the catalyst with Na, sodium carbonate was added to yield 0.40 wt% Na in the prepared Co-Mn catalyst. 20 mL deionized water was added to the mixture of the unpromoted Co-Mn catalyst and the Na precursor. After sufficient stirring, the mixture was dried in an oven at 110 °C for 12 h. The resulting solid was then subjected to further calcination in a muffle oven at 300 ℃ for 3 h under an air atmosphere to obtain N-Co2MnO4.5 catalyst. M−Co2MnO4.5 synthesis was done using the melting method. 6.01 g of glucose and 10.0 g of urea (glucose-urea mass ratio of 3:5) were melted in a 250 mL beaker at 120 ℃, with magnetic stirring at 400 rpm. When the solid glucose and urea turned into a transparent liquid after 30 min of agitation, 4.0 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O, a 2.5 g of a 50 wt% Mn(NO3)2 aqueous solution, and 0.0226 g anhydrous Na2CO3 (for 0.4 wt% Na content in the catalyst) were added to the beaker. The newly-formed mixture was stirred and heated for another 5 h, resulting in a purple-red viscous liquid. This was then heated in an oven at 180 °C for 24 h, and the liquid transformed into a foam-like black solid. The solid was then ground and calcined in a tube furnace at 400 ℃ for 2 h using Ar as the protective gas, which yielded a solid powder. The solid was then further calcination at 300 ℃ for 3 h in a muffle oven with static air, which yielded the M−Co2MnO4.5 catalyst sample. The procedure for catalyst preparation is illustrated in Fig. S1 of the Supplemental Information. P-Co2MnO4.5 was synthesized using a co-precipitation method similar to the procedure employed for N-Co2MnO4.5, but with a 2 M Na2CO3 solution as the precipitant. The same drying procedure was applied, but the resulting sample underwent a single calcination process in a muffle furnace at 330 °C for 3 h under an air atmosphere. 2.2 Characterization A nitrogen physisorption experiment was conducted to assess the pore structure of the catalyst samples using a Micromeritics 2420 instrument. Approximately 100 mg of the sample was degassed at 200 ℃ under vacuum for 10 h before the test. The specific surface area was determined using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation. The pore volume and average pore size were calculated using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. The hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiment was conducted using a Micromeritics Autochem-II 2920 instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The loaded sample was first degassed at 200 ℃ for 120 min and reduced under 5 % (v/v) H2/Ar gas from 50 ℃ to 800 ℃ at a rate of 10 ℃ min−1. An Agilent 7800 instrument was employed for precise analysis of the Co, Mn and Na contents in the catalyst samples using ICP-MS. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a D8 Advance X-ray Powder Diffractometer (40 kV, 40 mA) and Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54 Å) at a scanning rate of 2°/min. The semi-quantitative phase content was analyzed using the step scanning method with X-rays of Co Ka rays at 35° to 55°, using scanning rate of 0.2°/min and a retention time of 2 s. The phase content was calculated by the K-value method. A ZEISS Gemini SEM 300 scanning electron microscope (SEM) was used for morphological characterization and elemental mapping. It was equipped with an Aztec Energy X-Max 20 energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) detector. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) measurements were taken using a JEOL JEM-2100 electron microscope and using an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha, using Al Kα (hv = 1486 eV) as the radiation source. The binding energy of all spectra was calibrated by referencing the C 1 s neutral carbon peak at 284.6 eV. The XPS spectrum deconvolution was performed by using the Lorentzian-Gaussian functions after subtraction of a Shirley background. The X-ray absorption spectra (XAS), encompassing both the X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and the extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) of the sample at the Ni K-edge, were obtained at the TLS07A1 Beamline in the National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center (NSRRC), located in Taiwan. CO/H2O temperature-programmed surface reaction (CO/H2O-TPSR) experiments were conducted using a catalyst analyzer with mass spectrometry (BELCAT II + BelMass). The process involved weighing out 50 mg of the sample and adding it to a U-tube, then subjecting it to drying and pretreatment while raising the temperature from room temperature to 300 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. The system was then purged with He gas flow at 50 mL/min for 1 h and then cooled to 50 °C. Two gas streams − one for CO and the other for saturated water vapor − were continuously introduced to detect the CO2 signal via mass spectrometry. A ramping rate of 5 °C/min was applied from 100 °C to 260 °C, with each testing temperature being sustained for 10 min, while monitoring the CO2 effluent using a BelMass mass spectrometer (m/z = 44). 2.3 DFT calculation The Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) was used for the DFT calculations. The projector augmented wave (PAW) method and the Perdew-Burke-Emzerhof (PBE) semi-local exchange–correlation functionals were used for the energy evaluation. A cutoff energy of 450 eV was applied, and a convergence criterion for geometry relaxation was set, with the force acting on each atom being less than 0.05 eV/Å. Grimme’s DFT-D3 methodology was used to account for dispersion interactions. Throughout the computational process, a gamma-centered grid of 2 × 2 × 1 was used to sample the Brillouin zone. The energy threshold for defining the self-consistency of the electron density was set at 10-6 eV. To prevent interaction between neighboring images, a vacuum space of 15 Å was added along the z direction. 2.4 Catalyst evaluation and probe experiments 2.4.1 Catalyst evaluation The Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) reaction was conducted in a stainless steel fixed-bed reactor with an inner diameter of 8 mm and a length of 40 cm. The reactor was heated by a furnace equipped with three heating elements. A thermocouple situated at the center of the reactor tube was employed to measure the temperature of the catalyst bed. This temperature reading was utilized as the temperature condition for the catalyst tests. Typically, 1 g of catalyst (in powdered form) was compressed and shaped before loading it to the isothermal region of the reactor tube. The size of the loaded catalyst was 20–40 meshes. The catalyst was supported by stainless steel beads to enhance heat transfer. The catalyst was then reduced under a pure H2 flow at a rate of 3000 mL·g−1·h−1, at atmospheric pressure and at 300 ℃ for 15 h. The reactor was then cooled to 35 ℃, pressurized to 1 bar with a syngas flow (H2/CO = 1, 2) at a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 3000 mL·g−1·h−1. The reaction temperature was increased to 240 ℃ at a ramping rate of 5 ℃ min−1 to initiate the reaction. After passing through a hot trap (150 ℃) and a warm trap (50 ℃), the effluent gas from the reactor was analyzed online using an Agilent 8890 N gas chromatographer equipped with two FIDs and one TCD. For each set of reaction conditions employed in the experiment, a fresh catalyst was loaded and tested. The mass balance for carbon was calculated and maintained above 97 %. Consistent reproducibility of the catalyst studied was demonstrated through repeated experiments using the same reaction conditions. The CO conversion and product selectivity were determined using the following formulas: (1) X CO = 1 - CO % out × M F R out CO % in × M F R in (2) Se l C O 2 = C O 2 % out × M F R out CO % in × M F R in × X CO (3) Se l C n H m = n × C n H m % out × M F R out r CO × 1 - S e l C O 2 Where: CO % out and CO % in represent the CO molar fractions in the outlet and inlet gases, respectively; MF R out and MF R in represent the molar flowrates of the outlet and inlet gases. The olefin to paraffin ratio (O/P) was calculated using Eq. (4): (4) O / P = C n H 2 n % out C n H 2 n + 2 % out Where: C n H 2 n % out and C n H 2 n + 2 % out represent the molar fraction of olefin and paraffin for a specific carbon number, n, in the outlet gas. 2.4.2 WGSR probe experiments Probe experiments were conducted under consistent conditions to assess the WGSR activity of the catalysts with regard to the partial pressure of H2O and CO. Following the same reduction procedure as stated in section 2.4.1, the reduced catalyst sample was operated at 240°C, 0.1 MPa, and a WHSV of 3000 mL g-1h−1 under syngas conditions (H2/CO = 1) until the FTO performance reached a steady state. The hydrogen flow was then halted, and water was introduced into the reactor using a micro flow pump (CoMtro CP-M205). The off-gas, containing CO, CO2 and H2 was analyzed on the same Agilent 8890 GC. When characterizations were required for the spent catalyst, a passivation procedure was employed before unloading the catalyst. Initially, the reactor was purged with N2 for 12 h at the reaction temperature and then cooled to room temperature. A gas mixture containing 1 % O2 (with N2 as the balance gas) was introduced to the reactor to passivate the catalyst at atmospheric pressure for 4 h. After the passivation process was complete, the catalyst was unloaded and sealed for further characterization. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance The catalyst samples analyzed exhibited consistent elemental proportions (Table S1), but with differences in the preparation method used. The performance of the catalysts is shown in Table 1 and Fig. 1 . All three catalysts exhibit similar high selectivity for lower olefins under conditions of 240 °C, H2/CO = 1 and P = 0.1 MPa. The olefin selectivity for C2-C4 reaches 61.7 % for N-Co2MnO4.5, 60.5 % for M−Co2MnO4.5 and 58.4 % for P-Co2MnO4.5 when counting the hydrocarbons produced. For short-chain hydrocarbons in the C2-C4 range, olefin is overwhelmingly predominant with all three catalysts. For example, propylene constitutes over 95 % of the total C3 hydrocarbons − a highly desirable outcome for short-chain olefins. Similar hydrocarbon distributions (Fig. 1b) are also found for these catalysts. The detailed distribution of both olefins and paraffins for these three catalysts is illustrated in Figs. S2 and S3, and Table S2. Notably, N-Co2MnO4.5 demonstrates the highest selectivity (Entry 1, Table 1), perhaps due to the introduction of Na as the final step, which results in a higher Na content on the catalyst particle surface. Because of Na's strong electron effect, its catalytic activity is the lowest for the three samples. The M−Co2MnO4.5 catalyst prepared using the melting method, also exhibits high selectivity for short-chain olefins (Entry 3 and 4). More importantly, it demonstrates significantly lower CO2 selectivity than the other two catalysts under the same operating conditions and comparable CO conversions. Under an H2/CO ratio of 1:1, the CO2 selectivity is as low as 3.8 %, while the co-precipitated samples N-Co2MnO4.5 and P-Co2MnO4.5 show a CO2 selectivity as high as 42.6 % and 35.3 %, respectively. Researchers have noted the challenge of achieving both high selectivity for short-chain olefins and low CO2 selectivity with Co2C via the FTO [42]. Various methods were employed to address this challenge, primarily using hydrophobic materials to modify the catalyst surface and rapidly removing the water produced from the catalyst surface to create lower water vapor pressure, thereby achieving low WGSR activity. Correspondingly, CO2 selectivity can be reduced to about 15 % [37]. Despite the acknowledgment that high CO2 selectivity originates from high WGSR activity on the catalyst surface, the mechanism for high CO2 in the Na-promoted Co-Mn composite oxide system remains unclear, and was therefore the main focus of this work. Additionally, the catalyst obtained using the melting method demonstrated stable performance: over the measured 120 h, catalyst activity and the selectivity of each product showed no significant changes. (See Fig. 1c and 1d.). 3.2 Structural and morphological characterization 3.2.1 XRD analysis To unveil the structure–property relationship of the Co-Mn composite oxide catalysts prepared using various methods, XRD characterization was employed to determine the phases of the pristine, reduced and spent catalyst samples. As depicted in Fig. 2 , the diffraction intensity of the catalysts (31.26°, 36.82°, 44.83°, 55.77° and 59.47°) prepared using the three different methods corresponds to the characteristic peaks of Co2MnO4.5 (JCPDS#032–0297). This suggests that, despite the distinct preparation methods involved, the Co-Mn composite oxide catalysts obtained are identical in terms of phases. As indicated in Table S3, the average crystal size determined for the catalysts (using Scherrer's formula) wase 8.36 nm (N-Co2MnO4.5), 10.12 nm (M−Co2MnO4.5) and 11.63 nm (P- Co2MnO4.5). After subjecting the three catalysts to H2 reduction under identical conditions, all characteristic peaks of Co2MnO4.5 vanished. Meanwhile, differences in characteristic peaks were observed for the samples derived using the three different methods (Fig. 2b). The characteristic peaks of CoxMn1-xO at 35.95°, 41.75°, and 60.64° [42], along with a small intensity of Co0 at 44.46°, emerged for the N-Co2MnO4.5 and P- Co2MnO4.5. A pronounced peak intensity of Co0 at 44.46° appeared in the XRD spectra for the M−Co2MnO4.5 sample after reduction, while no CoxMn1-xO was identified. However, peaks for MnO were indexed at 35.63°, 41.30°, 51.45° and 59.49° (JCPDS#04–0326). The characteristic peaks of Co2C (JCPDS#89–4307) at 37.17°, 41.84°, 42.69° and 45.80° are present in all three catalyst samples after carburization and reaction, as shown in Fig. 2c. However, significant differences exist in the intensity of the Co2C peaks of the samples: the M−Co2MnO4.5 sample exhibiting much larger Co2C peak areas, which indicates a higher Co2C content. Moreover, the presence of MnO, but not CoxMn1-xO, supports the notion that more Co exists in the form of Co2C in this sample. In contrast, a weaker signal intensity of Co2C and a reduced CoxMn1-xO peak intensity is observed in the spent N-Co2MnO4.5 and P-Co2MnO4.5 samples. Notably, none of the working catalyst samples show characteristic peaks for Co0, which suggests that either cobalt exists in a non-reduced state or that cobalt clusters are too small to be detected by XRD. However, Co0 is clearly detected in the reduced M−Co2MnO4.5 sample, which indicates that the cobalt clusters are sufficiently large to be detected. Therefore, the XRD results suggest that Co0 is not present in the working catalyst samples to act as the active site, but with Co2C predominantly present in the M−Co2MnO4.5 catalyst and a mixture of Co2C and CoxMn1-xO in the N-Co2MnO4.5 and P-Co2MnO4.5 catalysts as the cobalt species. Two distinct evolution routes are evident for Co-Mn composite Co2MnO4.5 in catalysts prepared using the melting and co-precipitation methods. During the reduction stage, an apparent phase separation occurs for Co and Mn species in the M−Co2MnO4.5 catalyst prepared using the melting method. The successful liberation of Co from the Co-Mn composite structure facilitates the subsequent carburization reaction of Co, which results in a markedly high Co2C content in the spent catalyst sample. In contrast, the spinel structure remains for the Co-Mn composite oxide obtained by means of co-precipitation, and it transitions only to the partially reduced form, i.e. CoxMn1-xO. Due to the limited reduction of Co during this stage, the subsequent carburization process fails to extensively transform the Co oxide, CoxMn1-xO, fully into Co2C. The final working catalyst samples thus exhibit a significantly lower Co2C content than M−Co2MnO4.5. 3.2.2 SEM analysis The SEM images for the pristine catalyst samples are given in Fig. 3 ; the elemental mappings are provided in Fig. S4. The results illustrate a similar nanoparticle size for the three prepared catalysts after calcination, yet their morphologies exhibit distinctive features. The sample produced when using the melting method resulted in spherical nanoparticles with a uniform size and monodispersity. Even at a larger scale, the catalyst nanoparticles remain well-dispersed and show no signs of agglomeration. Conversely, the two catalysts prepared by co-precipitation exhibit a broader particle size distribution, with nano-sized particles further agglomerating to form large, blocky morphologies ranging in size from a few hundred nanometers to micrometers. Specifically, when (NH4)2CO3 was used as the precipitant, severe agglomeration occurred, which is possibly due to secondary calcination after Na impregnation. This suggests that differences in the microstructure of the catalyst during the precursor calcination process affect the morphology of the catalysts. The substantial variations in microstructure seen among the catalysts may influence their performance, particularly in terms of creating a micro-environment for reactants and products on the active sites. The particles of the three spent catalysts agglomerated and formed larger particles, which caused changes in particle size and dispersion. The increased particle size observed in all three catalysts after reaction, coupled with the XRD results above, may be due to the phase transformation of the catalyst from Co-Mn composite oxide to Co2C. However, after the reaction, the M−Co2MnO4.5 catalyst maintained its high dispersion pattern and uniform nanoparticle size. The well-dispersed nanoparticles in M−Co2MnO4.5 are a result of the preparation procedure used, as the precursors were thoroughly mixed and highly dispersed in molten glucose and urea. The subsequent urea decomposition at 180 °C sufficiently relaxed the molten syrup, which widened the space between the precursor droplets. Nanoparticles then formed from the droplets, with graphitic carbon wrappings acting as a barrier that prevented aggregation between particles during the calcination step. Following further carbon removal, the already-formed nanoparticles were uniformly dispersed and less prone to agglomeration. Therefore, the catalyst prepared using the melting method allows for control of particle size and morphology, which facilitates a refined catalyst design. The various preparation methods used resulted in variations in the surface areas of the catalysts. The surface areas and N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm curves for the three catalysts are detailed in Table S4 and Fig. S5, respectively. None of the three catalysts exhibited micropores, and the pore size distribution of the catalysts prepared using the co-precipitation method ranged from 5 to 15 nm, while that of the catalysts prepared using the melting method was 5 to 20 nm. 3.2.3 TEM analysis The HRTEM images of the pristine and spent catalyst samples are provided in Figs. 4 and 5 , respectively. Fig. 4 shows that the nanoparticle morphology of the three catalysts is predominantly spherical, with a small fraction of irregularly shaped particles. HRTEM results show lattice spacings of 4.72 Å and 2.89 Å in both the pristine N-Co2MnO4.5 and P-Co2MnO4.5 samples, which correspond to the (111) and (220) crystal facets of Co2MnO4.5. Only one lattice spacing of 4.72 Å (which corresponds to the (111) crystal facets of Co2MnO4.5) is observed in the pristine M−Co2MnO4.5 catalyst prepared using the melting method. The identified facets for all samples demonstrate Co2MnO4.5 crystals upon preparation, which aligns with the phase identification results obtained via XRD. Despite the pristine samples sharing the same phase composition, Co2MnO4.5, the catalysts that were investigated transformed into various active phases, as suggested by the HRTEM images in Fig. 5. A common characteristic for all three catalyst samples is the absence of Co2MnO4.5. This indicates it was transformed to other species during H2 reduction and carburization. In the case of M−Co2MnO4.5, Co2C is identified as the Co species with three crystalline facets identified − (101), (020) and (210) − and corresponding lattice spacings of 2.42, 2.19, and 1.98 Å, respectively. No partially reduced Co-Mn composite oxide, CoxMn1-xO, was identified. This suggests that the transformation from Co2MnO4.5 to Co0 and then to Co2C occurred to a significant extent. In contrast, CoxMn1-xO with crystalline facets of (111) and (220) was found in the spent N-Co2MnO4.5 and P-Co2MnO4.5 samples, although Co2C with a typical facet of (020) was also identified. This indicates that a considerable portion of the Co remains in the oxidized state, rather than as Co2C. Analysis of the spent M−Co2MnO4.5 sample also indicates the presence of MnO with crystalline facets of (120). This suggests that Mn was liberated from the Co2MnO4.5 structure, which supports the observation that Co was reduced to Co0. Conversely, no MnO was observed in the spent N-Co2MnO4.5 and P-Co2MnO4.5 samples where co-precipitation was applied. This confirms that the phase separation of the Co-Mn composite to form Co0 and MnO during the catalyst pretreatment stages was not achieved. The identified phases and their facets align well with the XRD analysis detailed in the previous section, and collectively indicate that the catalysts prepared using the melting and co-precipitation methods possess distinct compositions as active phases for the FTO. The data in Table 1 suggests that the significant difference in the phase composition had a limited effect on the selectivity of light olefins and the product distributions. This implies that both Na-promoted Co2C and CoxMn1-xO are active for the FTO and have high olefin selectivity. However, the CO2 selectivity is essentially affected by the phase composition, i.e. if CoxMn1-xO is primarily presented or not when the catalysts are designed in different ways. In previous studies, despite the catalysts exhibiting a significant amount of CoxMn1-xO, the researchers primarily focused on Co2C itself, due to its association with high olefin selectivity − a pivotal aspect of cobalt-based catalysts for the FTO. The experimental data and phase identification reported in this paper emphasize that both Na-promoted Co2C and CoxMn1-xO can lead to high olefin selectivity. The findings also indicate that high CO2 selectivity is closely tied to the presence of CoxMn1-xO, rather than Co2C. When the active catalyst achieves a high Co2C content, limited WGS activity is observed, which results in low CO2 selectivity. Previous studies [42,43] also attributed high CO2 selectivity in Co2C-based catalysts to the addition of Na, promoting higher WGSR activity. However, if Na plays a role in high CO2 selectivity, it appears to have a more pronounced effect on a catalyst with a higher CoxMn1-xO content rather than one with a high Co2C content, as suggested by data in this paper. 3.3 Effect of Co species on CO2 selectivity The preceding sections show that CO2 selectivity is determined by the active phases of the catalyst, with: one predominantly containing Co2C that results in low CO2 selectivity; and the other two exhibiting a mixture of CoxMn1-xO and Co2C, which leads to high CO2 selectivity. In addition, the high Co2C content is closely associated with significant liberation of Co from Co2MnO4.5 to Co0 during the reduction stage. To further understand the correlation between material surface properties and CO2 selectivity, H2-TPR-MS, XPS, XANES and EXAFS analyses were conducted for two catalysts (M−Co2MnO4.5 and P-Co2MnO4.5). These were prepared using the melting and co-precipitation methods, respectively. 3.3.1 H2-TPR-MS analysis The pristine M−Co2MnO4.5 and P-Co2MnO4.5 catalyst samples were characterized using H2-TPR-MS to analyze the catalyst reduction process and the production of H2O during reduction, as illustrated in Fig. 6 . The reduction curves for Co3O4 and Mn3O4, prepared using the melting method, are provided for reference purposes. The tail gas MS spectrometry data for M−Co2MnO4.5 and P-Co2MnO4.5 indicate that the reduction peaks of the two catalysts consumed hydrogen and generated water. The M−Co2MnO4.5 catalyst exhibits three reduction peaks (at 213 °C, 300 °C and 430 °C), while the P-Co2MnO4.5 catalyst displays two major reduction peaks at 325 °C and 458 °C. Close to the reduction peak at the low-temperature region for Mn3O4, a reduction peak emerged at 213 °C for the M−Co2MnO4.5 sample, which signifies phase separation of Co and Mn species in Co2MnO4.5. We posit that the reduction of Mn plays a pivotal role in phase separation and liberation of Co from the Co2MnO4.5 structure. The intensity of the peak at 210 °C may determine the final reduction extent of Co, which affects the Co2C fraction in the active catalyst sample. Notably, a peak was observed at the same temperature region for the P-Co2MnO4.5 sample, albeit with a milder intensity, which indicates the lesser extent of the phase separation of Co and Mn. The remaining two major reduction peaks beyond 300 °C shifted to a higher temperature in the P-Co2MnO4.5 sample, which suggests that the M−Co2MnO4.5 sample was more readily reducible. 3.3.2 XPS characterization XPS was employed to analyze the valence states of the elements in the three catalysts in their pristine, reduced, and carburized states. The complete XPS surveys of the catalysts are provided in Fig. S6. The Co 2p and Mn 2p spectra are shown in Fig. 7 and the calculated content of Co species are presented in Table S5. Given that reduced Co catalysts are prone to oxidation upon exposure to air, in-situ XPS analysis was used to examine the catalysts in a reduced state. Since the results for N-Co2MnO4.5 and P- Co2MnO4.5 are similar, the features of M−Co2MnO4.5 and P-Co2MnO4.5 will be discussed. Peaks corresponding to Co2+ (781.90 eV) and Co3+ (780.05 eV) were identified in Co 2p3/2 for the pristine catalysts prepared using both methods. According to the results shown in Table S5, the fitted peak areas suggest that the Co2+ and Co3+ content in the pristine M−Co2MnO4.5 catalyst sample was 17.4 % and 82.6 %, respectively. In the P-Co2MnO4.5 catalysts, it was 27.5 % and 72.4 %, respectively. After reduction by H2 the content of Co2+ in the M−Co2MnO4.5 catalyst decreased dramatically, and no peak of Co3+ was observed. (See Fig. 7c.) Notably, the peak of Co0 appeared at 799.89 eV with a content of 90.7 %, while the Co2+ content changed from 17.4 % to 9.3 %. This indicates that a substantial amount of Co2MnO4.5 was reduced to Co0, which is consistent with the XRD and HRTEM results provided in the previous sections. In contrast, the reduced P-Co2MnO4.5 catalyst sample contained much less Co0 (15.3 %), but a significant fraction of unreduced Co, with Co3+ at 60.13 % and Co2+ at 24.5 %. A high content in the high valence state of Co strongly suggests that the Co is still intertwined with Mn and O in the CoxMn1-xO structure. In the spent catalyst samples, the peak of Co0 disappeared in M−Co2MnO4.5, and the peak of Co2+ increased to a fraction as high as 94.3 %. Since the catalyst has been carburized and no cobalt oxides were identified, as suggested by the XRD results, the presence of Co2+ can therefore be attributed to Co2C. This indicates that a large amount of Co2C was generated after carburization and reaction. In contrast, the Co2+ content of N-Co2MnO4.5 and P-Co2MnO4.5 increased to 43.6 % and 58.4 %, respectively − see Table S5. This suggests that the amount of Co2C generated in these two catalysts was limited. Meanwhile, 56.4 % and 41.7 % of Co remained as Co3+, which indicates that a substantial fraction of CoxMn1-xO remained in both these catalysts. When Co is not freed from the Co-Mn structure, Mn is not freed either. Therefore, the variation in the valence state of Mn is a strong indication of the valence state of Co. After reduction, the valence state of Mn changes, and the Mn2+ peak appears at 640.35 eV. This suggests that Mn separates from Co-Mn composite oxides and exists in the form of MnO. Additionally, the Mn4+ content after the reaction is close to that in the reduced sample, which indicates the stable presence of MnO during the carburization process and the reaction. This is proof that Co has been successfully released from the Co-Mn composite during reduction of the catalyst, which leads to phase separation of Co2MnO4.5 into two separate crystals: MnO and Co0. However, in the two samples obtained via co-precipitation, a large fraction of Mn4+ can be observed in both the reduced and spent samples. This suggested that Co2MnO4.5 is partially reduced to CoxMn1-xO, which contains both Mn4+ and Mn2+. This further confirms that Mn has not been freed from the Co-Mn composite oxide. It also implies that transformation of the Co species into Co2C is limited, which is consistent with the phase characterization results detailed in Sections 3.2.1 and 3.2.3. 3.3.3 XANES and EXAFS analysis The XRD results suggest the presence of different phases of Co in the examined catalyst samples, while XPS analysis indicates varying valence states of Co in the active catalyst samples after carburization. However, it has been suggested that Co0 clusters on the surface of Co2C-based catalysts are crucial for achieving lower CO2 selectivity in the FTO reaction [39]. Since information about Co0 is not observable from XRD and XPS analyses, we conducted XANES and EXAFS for a more detailed analysis of the spent catalyst samples. The spectra are presented in Fig. 8 , and the calculated coordination numbers for Co with other elements, the fitting analysis of EXAFS spectra, as well as the wavelet transform (WT) analysis, are provided in Table S6 and Figs. S6 and S7, respectively. The XANES spectra in Fig. 8a reveal a gradual shift to the right in the curves, ranging from about 7709 to 7715 eV, indicating an increase in the Co valence state in both catalyst samples when compared to the Co-foil. The peaks emerging at about 7710 eV correspond to the 1 s to 3d orbital transition of Co, suggesting the presence of a centrosymmetric field due to Co2C [39,44,45]. Additionally, the surface Co on M−Co2MnO4.5 exhibits a lower valence state compared to P-Co2MnO4.5, which is consistent with the XPS results showing a higher proportion of Co3+ on the surface of P-Co2MnO4.5 and predominantly Co2+ on the surface of M−Co2MnO4.5. This observation is also consistent with the finding that Co in P-Co2MnO4.5 has a lower reduction degree compared to the M−Co2MnO4.5 catalyst. The EXAFS spectra provided in Fig. 8b further highlight the strengthening of the Co-C coordination peak at about 2.26 Å for the spent M−Co2MnO4.5 catalyst. Analysis of the EXAFS data (Fig. S7 and Table S6) suggests a coordination number of 4.1 ± 0.2 for the Co-C path in the M−Co2MnO4.5 catalyst, whereas the P-Co2MnO4.5 catalyst shows a value of 2.4 ± 0.2. Correspondingly, the coordination number of Co-O for M−Co2MnO4.5 is 1.2 ± 0.3, whereas for the P-Co2MnO4.5 catalyst, it is 2.2 ± 0.3. Both findings support the notion that the spent M−Co2MnO4.5 catalyst has a higher Co2C content. Analysis of the data also indicates the presence of Co-Co bonds in both catalyst samples, with coordination numbers of 4.1 ± 0.5 and 4.9 ± 0.6 for the M−Co2MnO4.5 and P-Co2MnO4.5 catalysts, respectively (Table S5). Given that metallic Co0 is undetectable by XRD, it likely exists in clusters, as suggested by findings in the literature [39]. The WT values (Fig. S8) also demonstrate similar strengths of Co-Co bonds on the surfaces of both catalysts, which indicate comparable levels of metallic Co contents. Therefore, the fine surface analysis of the catalysts further confirms that the primary reason for the different WGSR activities lies in the varying content of CoxMn1-xO, rather than metallic Co, in the catalyst samples. 3.3.4 Catalyst performance during transformation of Co0 to Co2C To further investigate whether the presence of metallic Co is the primary reason for the reduced WGSR activity, we examined the variation in CO2 selectivity during the transition from metallic Co0 to Co2C in the catalyst. The M−Co2MnO4.5 catalyst initially exhibited predominantly metallic Co once it was reduced by H2, which transformed into Co2C via carburization under syngas atmosphere as confirmed by the XRD and XPS results (see Figs. 2 and 7). We then monitored the dynamic phase changes during this transformation process (see Fig. S9) and recorded CO conversion, CO2 selectivity, and olefin selectivity (indicated by O/P ratios). The results are presented in Fig. 9 . Fig. S9 illustrates the transformation of the sample from metallic Co to Co2C over approximately 6 h. While we cannot precisely quantify the specific amounts of Co0 and Co2C during this 6-hour period with a finer characterization, we can ascertain that the catalyst transitions from a phase predominantly consisting of Co0 to one primarily composed of Co2C. Despite this transformation, the data in Fig. 9 suggest that the generation of Co2C from Co0 did not result in an increase in CO2 selectivity, which indicates that the formation of Co2C in this catalyst does not enhance WGSR activity. Additionally, significant changes in Co0 content did not lead to noticeable variation in catalyst activity. These results suggest that the activity and CO2 selectivity of this Na-promoted Co-Mn composite catalyst do not follow the common observation that metallic Co would provide a high catalytic activity and low CO2 selectivity. In addition, the olefin selectivity remains high when the active phase varies from Co0 to Co2C, as indicated by the olefin/paraffin ratios in Fig. 9b. This suggests that metallic Co⁰, under the promotion of Na and Mn, can also achieve high selectivity of olefins. We speculate that specific crystal planes of Co2C [28,42] are not the only factor in achieving high olefin selectivity. However, the result here does not conflict with the notion of facet effects influencing FTO performance reported in the literature. 3.4 WGSR activity on Co2C and Co oxides 3.4.1 WGSR probe experiments Despite using the same elements, the catalysts exhibited markedly different levels of CO2 selectivity. A detailed analysis of the structural and morphological aspects of the catalyst samples revealed differences in the quantity of Co2C and CoxMn1-xO in the active catalysts. Testing catalysts in reactors under various CO conversion conditions means there are variations in the H2O and CO partial pressure, which could affect the WGSR activity on the catalysts. In order to thoroughly determine the conformity of the relationship between CO2 selectivity and the active phases, WGSR probe experiments (Fig. 10 a and 10b) and CO/H2O-TPSR (Fig. 10c and 10d) were conducted using identical H2O and CO feed conditions. The catalysts prepared using the two methods exhibited similar FTO performance under a syngas atmosphere, which confirms the reproducibility of their performance. However, when switching from H2 to H2O, the WGSR activity varied significantly: the M−Co2MnO4.5 catalyst showed 17.6 % conversion and 99.2 % CO2 selectivity; the P-Co2MnO4.5 catalyst showed 65.0 % conversion and 99.0 % CO2 selectivity. Additionally, the much lower H2/CO ratio (Fig. 10a) in the off-gas of the M−Co2MnO4.5 also confirmed its lower WGSR activity. The TPSR-MS results (Fig. 10c and 10d) for both catalysts − performed at temperatures above 200 °C − indicated an enhanced CO2 signal intensity for the P-Co2MnO4.5 catalyst for the temperature range used for testing. At 240 °C, the temperature level used for the FTO experiments, the P-Co2MnO4.5 catalyst exhibited a CO2 signal intensity 2.9 times higher than that of the M−Co2MnO4.5 catalyst, which confirms that the melting method results in lower WGSR activity. With the additional data on the distinction in WGSR activity, it is evident that the active phases of the catalysts prepared using the two methods play a decisive role in determining CO2 selectivity. 3.4.2 DFT calculation of H2O adsorption on Co2C and Co oxides DFT calculations indicate that H2O exhibits much weaker adsorption on the Co2C surface than Co2MnO4.5. Since determining the atomic ratio of partially reduced CoxMn1-xO for the elements is impractical, Co2MnO4.5 was used in the calculations to simulate the adsorption energy of H2O on the surface of CoxMn1-xO. Typical Co2C crystalline facets (020) and (101), and Co2MnO4.5 facets (111) and (220), were constructed, and the simulation of H2O adsorption on these surfaces is illustrated in Fig. 11 . The promoter Na − in the form of Na2O − was incorporated in constructing the catalyst surfaces. The adsorption energies of H2O on the Co2C (020) and (101) surfaces were found to be −0.44 and −0.49 eV, respectively (Fig. 11a); for the Co2MnO4.5 (111) and (220) surfaces it was −1.25 and −1.34 eV, respectively (Fig. 11b). This indicates higher WGS activity on the Na-promoted Co2MnO4.5 surface. 3.4.3 Mechanism exploration of WGSR activity on a Co2C-based catalyst The findings provided above suggest that the heightened selectivity to CO2 observed in Co2C-based catalysts is due to the presence of CoxMn1-xO within the catalyst matrix. To delve deeper into the WGSR activity on CoxMn1-xO and explore the additional factors influencing CO2 selectivity in Co2C-based catalysts, we synthesized catalysts containing only CoxMn1-xO by excluding Na. FTO experiments were then conducted under identical conditions, as described above. The catalysts prepared using the melting and precipitation methods. In the absence of Na, the pristine catalyst samples revealed the presence of Co2MnO4.5, as indicated by the XRD spectra shown in Fig. S10. However, following reduction and carburization, neither transformed into Co2C; instead, they persisted in the form of CoxMn1-xO. Importantly, the successful reduction of Co2MnO4.5 to metallic Co and its subsequent transformation to Co2C were not influenced by the differences in the preparation methods used, but were contingent on the presence of Na. The product distribution of these catalysts typically exhibits a relatively high O/P ratio, elevated olefinic selectivity and commendable overall activity, albeit with pronounced CH4 selectivity. More importantly, when CoxMn1-xO served as the active phase, the catalyst did not exhibit high CO2 selectivity, which indicates the insignificant impact of WGS activity of CoxMn1-xO. Hence, the heightened WGSR activity observed in Na-promoted Co2C-based catalysts is determined by both the presence of CoxMn1-xO, as well as the addition of Na. We then systematically studied the Na effect on the catalysts prepared using the melting method, by varying the Na content from 0 up to 0.8 wt% (Table S7). The XRD patterns of the pristine and carburized (spent) catalyst samples are shown in Figs. S11 and S12, respectively. The CO2 selectivity, the catalyst performance, and the corresponding Co2C contents at different Na levels are given in Fig. 12 . The corresponding hydrocarbon product data are presented in Table S8 and the fine data analysis for the XRD spectra are provided in Fig. S13 and Table S9. Given that Na promotes WGSR to a different extent on Co2C and CoxMn1-xO, as discussed above, it is unsurprising that increasing the Na content from 0.4 % to 0.8 % in the catalyst prepared using the melting method resulted in sustained low CO2 selectivity levels. This outcome can be attributed to the high Co2C content in these catalyst samples, which confirms that Na does not enhance WGSR on Co2C. Conversely, with a relatively low Na content, CO2 selectivity increases in the 0.1–0.3 range, in correspondence with the increment in Na content. Close examination of the physical phases shown in Fig. 12 and Fig. S13 reveals that, in this Na content range, CoxMn1-xO content in the catalyst is higher than with a high Na content. The same study was conducted for the Co-Mn catalysts prepared by the co-precipitation method, with Na content ranging from 0.1 to 0.6 % (Table S10). The performance of these catalysts, along with the corresponding Co2C and CoxMn1-xO contents, is presented in Fig. S14. Detailed reaction data are provided in Table S11, while XRD analysis spectra and calculated phase compositions are shown in Fig. S15 and Table S12, respectively. The CO2 selectivity ranges from 21.3 % to 35.8 %, significantly higher than those observed for the catalyst samples prepared by the melting method. Correspondingly, consistently high fractions of CoxMn1-xO (26.2 %–33.8 %) are observed in these catalyst samples, similar to previous studies utilizing the same co-precipitation method for catalyst preparation [42]. Therefore, creating a structural condition conducive to easy phase separation between Co and Mn is pivotal to determining the ultimate Co2C content in the active catalyst. It is crucial to note that the elemental species and compositions used to prepare the catalysts via both methods was identical, as confirmed by the ICP results in Table S1. The characterization results also suggest that the structure is Co2MnO4.5 for the freshly prepared catalysts, and that the crystallinity and particle sizes are comparable. The primary difference that leads to this result is probably how Na interacts with the Co-Mn composite structure, as the absence of Na fails to facilitate phase separation for Co2MnO4.5 during the H2 reduction stage (Fig. S9). The melting method highly possibly enables adequate mixing of Co, Mn and Na to a homogeneous state during preparation. The well-dispersed Na, adjacent to the Co-Mn structure, facilitates easy phase separation of Co and Mn species. Given the presence of Co2C, partially reduced Co oxide, CoxMn1-xO, the promoter Na, and the interactions between them, the mechanism behind the elevated CO2 selectivity in Co2C-based catalysts is not a simple one, as other affecting factors may not be identified in this study. High CO2 selectivity, resulting from high WGSR activity, may originates from the presence of the partially reduced Co-Mn composite oxide, CoxMn1-xO, or in another word, higher Co-O coordination due to the presence of CoxMn1-xO. However, CoxMn1-xO itself (high Co-O coordination) exhibits limited WGSR activity only, while the presence of Na strongly boosts its WGSR activity, even at reduced H2O partial pressure, as lower conversion figures are obtained when Na is added. The evidence presented in this work suggests that Co2C does not exhibit obvious WGSR activity, since low CO2 selectivity is consistently observed when the catalyst has a high Co2C content (higher Co-C coordination). Additionally, Na is one of the factors that promotes WGSR activity over a Co2C-based catalyst, but its promotional effect on WGSR does not occur through Co2C, but rather through CoxMn1-xO. High CO2 selectivity is only observed when both CoxMn1-xO and Na are simultaneously present in the catalyst, i.e. the presence of either one alone does not lead to high CO2 selectivity. Similarly, even when Na is present at a higher concentration, the catalyst still exhibits lower WGSR activity, as long as the catalysts contain primarily Co2C as the active phase. Based on the differences in phase transformations during the reduction and carburization processes of the catalysts, as well as the resulted variations in WGSR activity, we propose a possible model describing the relationship between the phase evolution of Co2C-based catalysts and CO2 selectivity, as presented in Fig. 13 . 4 Conclusion This study investigates the CO2 selectivity of Co2C-based catalysts and provides insights into the potential origin of resulting in high CO2 selectivity under low-temperature FTO conditions. Na-promoted Co2C catalysts, synthesized using both the melting method and the co-precipitation method with equivalent elemental contents, demonstrate similarly high selectivity toward short-chain olefins. However, drastic differences in CO2 selectivity exhibit, with the melting method yielding 3.8 % and the co-precipitation method yielding 35.3 %. Thorough phase characterization, as the catalysts transition from pristine to reduced and carburized states, reveals that high CO2 selectivity originates from CoxMn1-xO, or high Co-O coordination, when phase separation of Co and Mn species from the Co-Mn composite structure is not achieved. However, CoxMn1-xO alone does not exhibit high WGSR activity, while the CO2 formation reaction on the surface of CoxMn1-xO is greatly accelerated with Na promotion. As the widely focused active phase, Co2C itself does not display strong WGSR activity. Close CO conversion and CO2 selectivity are observed when the Co phase transforms from Co0 to Co2C, indicating that, with Na as a promoter, both Co0 and Co2C exhibit similar catalytic performance. Increasing the Na content up to 0.8 wt% fails to elevate the CO2 selectivity of the catalysts, as long as the Co2C content is at high levels. However, catalysts with low Na contents (0.1–0.3 wt%) prepared using the melting method exhibit relatively high CO2 selectivity. This may be due to the presence of fractional CoxMn1-xO in the catalyst, as an insufficient amount of Na fails to liberate Co from the Co-Mn composite structure to a great extent, hindering its conversion to Co2C. This study explains the possible origin that drives high CO2 selectivity in Co2C-based catalysts for FTO based on the phase identification and mechanistic experiments, and offers a simple yet highly effective strategy for designing Co2C-based catalysts with low CO2 selectivity, while achieving high selectivity for short-chain olefins. coredata.dc:description: The Co2C-based catalyst is a promising candidate for the Fischer-Tropsch to olefins reaction. However, it consistently exhibits high CO2 selectivity (∼40 %), and the origin of the high activity in the water–gas-shift reaction is not well-understood. In this study, Co2C catalysts constructed with the same elemental compositions but using the melting and co-precipitation methods resulted in drastic differences in CO2 selectivity − one at 3.8 % and the other at 35.3 %. A detailed structural study revealed that the presence of CoxMn1-xO instead of Co2C is responsible for the elevated CO2 selectivity. Interestingly, CoxMn1-xO alone demonstrates limited CO2 selectivity, but when promoted with Na, its WGSR activity is greatly enhanced. Conversely, the catalysts maintained consistently low CO2 selectivity even with improved Na content, as long as a high fraction of Co2C is present. This finding is important for designing Co2C-based catalysts that can achieve high olefin selectivity while minimizing undesirable CO2 emissions.
